title: 107_s870
content: The Act is titled the "Multimodal Transportation Financing Act" and allows tax-exempt financing for qualified highway infrastructure. The "Multimodal Transportation Financing Act" allows tax-exempt financing for qualified highway infrastructure projects, including construction, reconstruction, and maintenance of highways. The "Multimodal Transportation Financing Act" allows tax-exempt financing for qualified highway infrastructure projects that serve the general public, are located on publicly-owned rights-of-way, and are publicly owned or revert ownership to the public. Amendments exempt certain bonds from state volume caps. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow for tax-exempt financing of qualified highway infrastructure projects, including environmental enhancements of hydroelectric generating facilities. Certain bonds are exempt from state volume caps under the "Multimodal Transportation Financing Act". Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow tax-exempt financing for infrastructure projects, excluding qualified 501(c)(3) bonds. Special rules apply for bonds issued before October 22, 1986, regarding refunding and advance refunding. Before March 15, 1986, a bond issued as part of an advance refunding of the original bond shall be treated as the 1st advance refunding if certain conditions are met, including using at least 95% of the net proceeds for a highway infrastructure project and being primarily secured by project-based revenues. The original and refunding bonds must meet certain requirements if they are private activity bonds used to finance a qualified highway infrastructure project. The second generation advance refunding bonds of the issue satisfy the requirements of section 147(b), with a special rule for certain highway infrastructure projects. The remaining weighted average maturity of escrowed bonds is determined based on whether the original bonds are private activity bonds or not, for both first and second generation advance refunding. The effective date for the amendments applies to bonds issued after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. MASS COMMUTING FACILITIES. This section amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt mass commuting facilities from the state volume cap and includes rolling stock related to such facilities. The amendments apply to bonds issued after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. MODIFICATION OF DEFINITION OF HIGH-SPEED INTERCITY RAIL FACILITIES. Amends the definition of high-speed intercity rail facilities in the Internal Revenue Code to include high-speed rail corridors designated under title 23, United States Code, or corridors using magnetic levitation technology. Effective for bonds issued after the enactment of this Act. (a) Treatment as Exempt Facility Bond.--Section 142 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include intermodal transfer facilities as exempt facility bonds. Intermodal transfer facilities refer to facilities for transferring people or goods between different transportation modes. This amendment exempts intermodal transfer facilities from general state volume caps under section 146(g) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 146(g) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include intermodal transfer facilities. Section 147(d)(3) is also amended to include intermodal transfer facilities. Subsection (c) of section 142 is amended accordingly. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include High-Speed Intercity Rail Facilities and Intermodal Transfer Facilities. The amendments apply to bonds issued after the date of enactment of this Act.
